summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 among US Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing scheduling a call regarding the Epstein probate case. It includes a forwarded update from February 2020 detailing legal disputes between the Epstein estate executors and the Virgin Islands Attorney General over victim compensation and asset liens.

persons.name: Denise George
persons.context: The Attorney General of the US Virgin Islands who brought charges against Epstein's estate, alleged fraud by his lawyers, placed liens on estate assets, and made demands for a victim compensation program.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Named by Epstein as an executor of his will; alleged by the Virgin Islands AG to have potentially been part of Epstein's alleged fraud.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.context: Named by Epstein as an executor of his will; alleged by the Virgin Islands AG to have potentially been part of Epstein's alleged fraud.

persons.name: Bennet Moskowitz
persons.context: Represented Epstein's estate in court, claiming liens by the Virgin Islands AG prevented releasing money for a victim compensation fund.

persons.name: Ken Feinberg
persons.context: Noted as the proposed overseer of a voluntary resolution program for Epstein's accusers, having previously managed major compensation funds.

persons.name: Edward Helmore
persons.context: Author of a Guardian article about the dispute between Epstein's estate lawyers and the Virgin Islands AG.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier whose estate is the subject of the probate proceedings, victim claims, and investigations.

connections.description: Both were named by Jeffrey Epstein as executors of his will and are alleged by the Virgin Islands AG to have potentially facilitated his fraud.
Indyke served as Epstein's lawyer and was named as an executor in his will.
Kahn served as Epstein's lawyer and was named as an executor in his will.
Moskowitz is the attorney representing the Epstein estate, of which Indyke is an executor.
Moskowitz is the attorney representing the Epstein estate, of which Kahn is an executor.
The Virgin Islands AG brought charges against the Epstein estate and alleged Indyke may have been part of Epstein's fraud.
The Virgin Islands AG brought charges against the Epstein estate and alleged Kahn may have been part of Epstein's fraud.

events.title: Virgin Islands AG Demands on Epstein Estate
events.description: Virgin Islands Attorney General Denise George sent a letter to the Epstein estate executors laying out demands for a victim compensation program, including cooperation with investigations, waiving NDAs, and providing a complete asset inventory.

events.title: Probate Court Denies Virgin Islands AG Intervention
events.description: The probate court denied the Virgin Islands Attorney General's motion to intervene in the Epstein probate proceedings.

events.title: Estate Files for Emergency Relief
events.description: The executors of Epstein's estate moved the probate court for emergency relief to gain full access to the estate's frozen funds to pay administrative expenses without the Virgin Islands AG's prior approval.

events.title: Virgin Islands AG Brings Charges Against Estate
events.description: Virgin Islands Attorney General Denise George brought charges against Epstein's estate and alleged his lawyers, Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn, may have been part of Epstein's alleged fraud. She also placed claims on Epstein's two islands.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in a Manhattan jail cell.

events.title: Epstein's Federal Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on fresh federal sex trafficking and conspiracy charges.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to a Florida state prostitution charge and served a 13-month jail sentence.

locations: Epstein's two islands (in the Virgin Islands)
keyFacts: The Virgin Islands Attorney General, Denise George, alleged that Epstein's lawyers and estate executors, Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn, may have been part of Epstein's alleged fraud.
The Virgin Islands AG placed liens on Epstein's estate assets, freezing bank accounts and demanding prior approval for all expenditures, which the estate executors are challenging in court.

The Virgin Islands AG made specific demands for a victim compensation program, including that the estate cooperate with investigations, waive NDAs for former employees, and not require third-party releases from victims.

Epstein's estate had proposed a victim compensation fund overseen by Ken Feinberg, but the Virgin Islands AG opposed it as lacking fairness and accountability, and some victim lawyers argued it would maintain secrecy.
Epstein modified his will two days before his death to have it executed in the US Virgin Islands, naming Darren Indyke and Richard Kahn as executors.
